title.narrative: Dinka Agar Internal Cattle Migration Process.

description.narrative: In November 2020, the Dinka Agar five sections sat and discussed how to regulate cattle movement to toc (grazing lands). Cattle movement and claim of toc ownership has been the root causes of many intra-communal conflicts across the Dinka Agar. The gelweng leaders and traditional leaders have identified the unregulated cattle movement as the primary trigger of intra-communal conflict between the Dinka Agar sections. In November 2020, the internal cattle migration conference concluded with resolutions that would regulate the cattle movement, including an agreement to perform a ritual that marked the migration to toc. However, the monitoring committee could not be formed due to the lack of state government, leading to the agreement violation. The progress of the 2020 migration season needs to be consolidated in the 2021 season, building on the lessons of the first cycle. The proposed approach will be through: - Engaging those directly responsible for initiating violence: the risks of engagement with armed actors need to be overcome. - Working through traditional structures, practices and leadership: prioritising and valuing traditional conflict management mechanisms at the community level. - Keeping the external politics at the appropriate distance: maintaining an authorising environment through engagement with elites and government, keeping them updated, and maintaining ownership at the community level. - Working with trusted local partners: taking time to understand and triangulate the dynamics of the local actors, then working closely alongside those who can facilitate entry points. - Capturing experiences and learning: ensuring that challenges are not dismissed, but documented, discussed and any adaptations and lessons moving forward are made explicit and then operationalised.
